meta.name: title
meta.content: My dad owns a pizza shop in a village full of pizza shops. How to make it stand out?

meta.name: description
meta.content: My dad owns a pizza shop in a village full of pizza shops. Quite a large village but there s about 7 pizza shops 3 Chinese 2 Indian and loads of chip shops. Business has been really quiet recently. It used to be heaving before they all opened but now it s so quiet. We have a buy one get one free on pizza 2 days a week but even them are starting to get quiet now. Any ideas or tips on how to make it busier again would be much appreciated. We are in the middle of handing menu s out as well. Thanks x

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: yahoo, answers, questions, Local Businesses,United Kingdom,Other - United Kingdom
My dad owns a pizza shop in a village full of pizza shops. How to make it stand out?

My dad owns a pizza shop in a village full of pizza shops. Quite a large village but there s about 7 pizza shops 3 Chinese 2 Indian and loads of chip shops. Business has been really quiet recently. It used to be heaving before they all opened but now it s so quiet. We have a buy one get one free on pizza 2 days a week but even them are starting to get quiet now. Any ideas or tips on how to make it busier again would be much appreciated. We are in the middle of handing menu s out as well. Thanks x

div.span:
My dad owns a pizza shop in a village full of pizza shops. Quite a large village but there s about 7 pizza shops 3 Chinese 2 Indian and loads of chip shops. Business has been really quiet recently. It used to be heaving before they all opened but now it s so quiet. We have a buy one get one free on pizza 2 days a week but even them are starting to get quiet now. Any ideas or tips on how to make it busier again would be much appreciated. We are in the middle of handing menu s out as well.
Thanks x

ul.class: D-b Bgc-w Lh-16 Bdstart-1g Bdend-1g Pb-0

div.span:
It's up to your father to make it stand out. He owns the shop.
Make the building look unique. Make it where people can tell that the shop is there, and that the shop is open when regular business hours are happening. Have plenty of parking spaces for people. Have various types of pizza (toppings), and make the pizza have its own taste. For example, Pizza Hut pizza does not taste like Papa John's pizza, which, in turn, does not taste like Little Caezar's pizza. Sell more than just pizza. Also sell hot wings and bread sticks. And pop (soda). If the pizza is slightly bigger than most pizza place's have, it will be better for your dad's shop. If there's a dining room for people to eat in, in the building, instead of it being take out only, that will help. Sometimes, people, like me, or elderly people, would want to sit down and eat it right then. Or, at least, sit down while waiting on the pizza to be made. Two chairs at the door is not enough to accommodate that. Most other places only have two chairs at the door. If the shop also has deals, like coupons or buy one get one free, or something like that, it will help. Your dad could also give any and all left over pizza, that was not sold, to a homeless shelter daily or weekly. That will definitely stand out. Instead of throwing the perfectly good food out, which ALL other places do (not just pizza places), that food would be going to a good cause. Helping people who cannot help themselves. People who would otherwise literally starve to death. And, it's bad to waste food, anyway. Also, like Paladin said, use real ingredients. Even Clive had a good idea. Make 'em square.
Bonus idea: Since your father owns the shop, whatever he does not give to a homeless shelter or throw out, it could go to his house and your house for you and him to eat. But, nobody outside the shop needs to know that, if that happens. He could also have an annual thing where he lets the employees take home the extra pizza. Especially at holidays, like Thanksgiving and Christmas. Again, only the company would know that.

div.span:
Focus on the quality of your ingredients. These days most pizza places are using cheap processed cheese and canned sauce. Talk about how your tomato sauce is homemade based on a 100 year old recipe. How you only use the best cheese, not processed cheese that is full of oil. Focus on using fresh vegetables, not canned or frozen. If you have any butchers nearby, then use their meats and get them to co-advertize with you
Do a blind taste test in a public location. Get a pizza from the other places, cut them into small pieces and put them on plates numbering 1-5. Then have people vote for the best pizza and give one sentence about each pizza about why they liked or didn't like it. Give them a free can of soda or candy bar or something after they complete the survey. Just don't let them know it's for your pizza place. If yours wins, then you can advertise that "in a blind taste test, our pizza came out the winner". If yours doesn't win, then find out what people are saying about the others -- good and bad, and what comments they had about yours

div.span:
How about a delivery service (you don't mention if you do that or not already). Getting pizza delivered is very common in America, but overseas I've heard it is sometimes rare. You could have a limited delivery area to start out with, say delivery to businesses at lunch time just to see if it works.
Do you have a room you can set aside for groups to use for events? People could reserve it for meetings and such with you providing the catering, so to speak. It is surprisingly hard to find places where you can have lunch meetings that involve more than four people! If you can provide a video screen for projection or a tv where people can watch sporting events, then that is a bonus.
How about a 'stunt' or 'gimmick' item, like a "giant" sized pizza, and/or "if you can eat the whole thing within 15 minutes it is free". The idea is just to get people to visit the restaurant, maybe bring some friends.
Go outside, and walk up and down the street a few times and try to judge how appealing your restaurant looks to people from the outside - does it look welcoming, or dark and closed? How easily can you tell it is a pizza place?
You should also get some kind of feedback on the quality of your food - perceptions of quality change over time, so if you are doing it the same way always have, current visitors may not like the result.
What about your online presence - are you part of any services where people can order online and pick up their order to go, or for delivery? Can you offer and advertise wifi access for people visiting your restaurant?
Finally, I'd spend some time investigating just what the preferences are of your customer base - are they young, old, rich, poor, maybe people are seeking healthy options, or you need to cater to ethnic tastes, etc. Also, don't be shy about visiting other pizza places and trying to figure out what works or doesn't work for them.
Here are some articles that may give you some ideas:
We order once a week on a Monday night and spend up to ¬£21: The nation's pizza habits revealed... and pepperoni is our favourite topping
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/food/article-3064318/The-nation-s-pizza-habits-revealed.html
Top ten most popular pizzas in the UK revealed - is your favourite on the list?
http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/pizzas-most-widely-available-you-6463227

div.span: don't think too hard. simple is best. people like clean, and tasty. nothing trumps those too attributes. Second, there are 5 senses to a human being appeal to sight, sound, physical accommodations, smell and taste. thirdly, you are services business make sure you are dependable and consistent in a timely way -make sure you serve up the a product the same way in the same time every time. give folks heads up when you can't meet those exepctations. forth, you are a hospitality industry make sure you greet every patron, attend to every patron, and make sure they leave with a smile. sixth, stick menu items that sell becuase nothing says more than a busy place that locals frequent. I was trained by a person that owns the #1, #2, #3, #4, and #5 highest grossing restaurants in Virginia, United States. I also consult. keep in touch.

div.span:
You've got to do something to make it stand out. Some suggestions:
1. In your advertising, tell some intriguing story about the pizza shop or your Dad. Hell, make it up if you have to. Something like, "When the Godfather Corleone wanted a pizza just like his mama in Italy used to make, he had a contest that the man who made the pizza like his mama used to make, would win $10,000 to open his own pizzeria! I won that contest and now I sell that same pizza to you and your family."
2. Karaoke night!
3. Do you deliver? If not, do it. Make sure those menus you hand out proudly state that you will deliver FOR FREE. And hand them out anywhere, including hotels and businesses, within a 3 mile radius.

div.span:
You have reached the pizza shop event horizon. It will only get worse until most of them close down, and those that are left will be so badly paid it will hardly be worth it.
You have to change the game if you want to survive as you will be up against big names with national advertising. Don't compete with them - be different!

Beautiful interior, superb service, let your place clean and other services that they don't offer like complementary drinks or coupons, etc.

div.div: My dad owns a pizza shop in a village full of pizza shops. How to make it stand out?

div.class: ya-answer-box-toggle-desc Cur-p Ol-n Pos-a T-0 R-0 Wpx-20 Hpx-20 shared-sprite answer-box-downbeak

div.div:
My dad owns a pizza shop in a village full of pizza shops. Quite a large village but there s about 7 pizza shops 3 Chinese 2 Indian and loads of chip shops. Business has been really quiet recently. It used to be heaving before they all opened but now it s so quiet. We have a buy one get one free on pizza 2 days a week but even them are starting to get quiet now. Any ideas or tips on how to make it busier again would be much appreciated. We are in the middle of handing menu s out as well.
Thanks x
